questions.question: Under ASC 842, a lease is classified as a finance lease by the lessee if:

options.A: The lease term is more than 12 months
options.B: The present value of lease payments is substantially all of the asset's fair value
options.D: The lessor is a related party

questions.explanation: Finance lease criteria include: (1) transfer of ownership, (2) purchase option reasonably certain, (3) lease term is major part of useful life, (4) PV of payments is substantially all of FV, or (5) specialized asset with no alternative use.
questions.tip: Finance lease: ownership transfer, BPO, major term, substantially all FV, specialized asset.

questions.question: Compared to an operating lease, a finance lease results in:

options.A: Lower total expense over the lease term
options.B: Higher expense in early years due to interest frontloading
options.D: Linear expense recognition throughout the term

questions.explanation: Finance leases have higher expense in early years because interest on the lease liability is higher initially (calculated on a larger balance) while amortization is typically straight-line. Operating leases have level expense.
questions.tip: Finance lease = front-loaded expense; Operating = straight-line expense.

questions.question: The initial measurement of a right-of-use asset includes all of the following EXCEPT:

options.B: Lease payments made before commencement
options.D: Executory costs such as insurance and maintenance

questions.explanation: ROU asset = Lease liability + prepaid lease payments + initial direct costs - lease incentives received. Executory costs are expensed as incurred, not capitalized.
questions.tip: ROU asset excludes executory costs (insurance, maintenance, taxes).

questions.question: A 5-year lease has annual payments of $50,000 (beginning of period), PV factor 4.4 at 8%. The lessee paid $10,000 in initial direct costs and received a $5,000 incentive from the lessor. What is the initial ROU asset?
questions.tip: ROU = Lease liability + initial direct costs - lease incentives.

questions.question: If the rate implicit in a lease is not readily determinable, the lessee should use:

options.B: The lessee's incremental borrowing rate

questions.explanation: Lessees use the rate implicit in the lease if determinable; otherwise, they use their incremental borrowing rate (the rate they would pay on a similar collateralized loan).
questions.tip: Lessee: implicit rate if known, else incremental borrowing rate.

questions.question: Which variable lease payments are included in the initial lease liability measurement?

options.A: Payments based on a percentage of sales
options.B: Payments tied to an index or rate (e.g., CPI)
options.C: Payments based on usage or mileage

questions.explanation: Variable payments based on an index or rate are included in the lease liability using the index/rate at commencement. Payments based on sales, usage, or performance are expensed as incurred.
questions.tip: Index-based variable payments = included; sales/usage-based = expensed when incurred.

questions.question: A lease modification should be accounted for as a separate lease if:

options.A: The modification extends the lease term
options.B: The modification adds the right to use additional assets that are distinct, with commensurate price increase
options.C: The modification decreases the lease term
options.D: The modification changes only the payment amounts

questions.explanation: A modification is a separate lease when it adds a distinct right to use additional assets AND the increase in consideration is commensurate with the standalone price for that right.
questions.tip: Separate lease: additional distinct asset + standalone pricing.

questions.question: When a lease modification decreases the scope of the lease (partial termination), the lessee should:

options.A: Continue accounting for the original lease without adjustment
options.B: Reduce the ROU asset and lease liability proportionately and recognize any difference in P&L
options.D: Write off the entire ROU asset

questions.explanation: For a partial termination, the lessee proportionately decreases both the ROU asset and lease liability. Any difference between these adjustments is recognized as a gain or loss.
questions.tip: Partial termination: proportionate reduction to ROU and liability; difference = gain/loss.

questions.question: A lessee has a 5-year lease with two 3-year renewal options. The asset is essential to operations with no alternative location. What is the most likely lease term?

options.B: 8 years

questions.explanation: When the asset is essential to operations with significant economic incentive to renew (no alternative location), renewal options are likely reasonably certain to be exercised. Lease term = 5 + 3 + 3 = 11 years.
questions.tip: Essential asset + no alternatives = renewals likely reasonably certain.

questions.conceptTested: Including purchase option in lease liability
questions.question: A 4-year lease has annual payments of $20,000 and a $15,000 purchase option that is reasonably certain to be exercised. Using a 6% rate (PV factors: 4-year annuity = 3.465, 4-year single = 0.792), what is the lease liability?
questions.tip: Include PV of purchase option if reasonably certain to exercise.

questions.question: A lessee provides a $10,000 residual value guarantee. At lease end, the asset's actual residual value is $7,000. What is the lessee's liability?
questions.explanation: The lessee's obligation is limited to the difference between the guaranteed amount and actual residual value: $10,000 - $7,000 = $3,000.
questions.tip: RVG liability = guaranteed amount - actual residual (if positive).

questions.question: A company can elect to not recognize a ROU asset and lease liability for leases with a term of:

options.B: 12 months or less at commencement (without purchase option likely to exercise)

questions.explanation: The short-term lease exemption applies to leases with a term of 12 months or less at commencement and that don't include a purchase option the lessee is reasonably certain to exercise.
questions.tip: Short-term election: ≤12 months, no likely purchase option.

questions.question: A finance lease has a $100,000 ROU asset (5-year life, straight-line) and $100,000 lease liability at 8%. Year 1 expense (interest + amortization) is approximately:
questions.tip: Finance lease expense = amortization + interest.

questions.question: An operating lease has annual payments of $10,000 for Years 1-3, then $15,000 for Years 4-5. What is the annual straight-line lease expense?
questions.tip: Operating lease expense = total payments ÷ lease term (straight-line).

questions.question: A lessor should classify a lease as sales-type rather than direct financing when:

options.A: The lease term is over 5 years
options.B: The fair value of the asset differs from its carrying amount (profit exists)
options.C: The lessee is a new customer

questions.explanation: For a lessor, if a finance lease exists AND the fair value differs from carrying amount (i.e., selling profit/loss exists), it's sales-type. If FV equals carrying amount, it's direct financing.
questions.tip: Sales-type = profit at inception; Direct financing = no profit at inception.

questions.question: A lessor enters a sales-type lease. Asset carrying value is $80,000, fair value is $100,000. PV of lease payments is $95,000 with an unguaranteed residual of $5,000 (PV). What profit is recognized at inception?
questions.explanation: In a sales-type lease, Revenue = PV of lease payments = $95,000. Cost of goods sold = Carrying value - PV of unguaranteed residual = $80,000 - $5,000 = $75,000. Gross profit at inception = $95,000 - $75,000 = $20,000. The unguaranteed residual reduces COGS because the lessor retains the expected residual value.
questions.tip: Sales-type lease profit: Revenue (PV payments) - (Carrying value - PV unguaranteed residual).

questions.question: For an operating lease, the lessor:

options.A: Removes the asset from its books
options.B: Keeps the asset on its books and continues to depreciate it
options.C: Records a lease receivable equal to total payments
options.D: Recognizes all revenue at lease inception

questions.explanation: In an operating lease, the lessor retains the asset, continues to depreciate it, and recognizes lease income on a straight-line basis over the lease term.
questions.tip: Lessor operating lease: keep asset, depreciate, recognize income over term.

questions.question: A lessor's direct financing lease has PV of lease payments of $200,000 and PV of unguaranteed residual of $20,000. The asset's carrying value equals its fair value of $220,000. What is the net investment in the lease?
questions.explanation: Net investment = Lease receivable (PV payments + PV residual) = $200,000 + $20,000 = $220,000. No profit at inception in direct financing lease.
questions.tip: Net investment = PV payments + PV unguaranteed residual.

questions.question: In a sale-leaseback transaction, for the transfer to qualify as a sale, the leaseback must:

options.A: Be classified as an operating lease
options.B: Not give the seller-lessee control over the asset
options.C: Satisfy the control transfer criteria under ASC 606
options.D: Be for at least 75% of the remaining useful life

questions.explanation: For a sale-leaseback to qualify as a sale, the transfer must satisfy ASC 606 control criteria. If the leaseback is a finance lease or the buyer-lessor has a repurchase option, it typically fails.
questions.tip: Sale-leaseback: must meet ASC 606 sale criteria.

questions.question: If a sale-leaseback fails to qualify as a sale, the seller-lessee should account for the transaction as:

options.B: A financing arrangement

questions.explanation: When a sale-leaseback fails to qualify as a sale, the seller-lessee keeps the asset on its books and records a financing liability for the proceeds received.
questions.tip: Failed sale-leaseback = keep asset, record financing liability.

questions.question: A company sells a building (CV $500,000, FV $800,000) and leases it back with an operating lease for 5 years (25% of remaining 20-year life). How much gain is recognized at sale?
questions.explanation: Since the leaseback is an operating lease (25% of life, not substantially all), control transfers and it qualifies as a sale. Full gain = $800,000 - $500,000 = $300,000 is recognized immediately.
questions.tip: Successful sale-leaseback with minor leaseback = full gain recognition.

questions.question: When classifying a sublease, the original lessee (now sublessor) should evaluate the sublease based on:

options.B: The right-of-use asset from the head lease
options.C: The fair value of the property
options.D: The remaining term of the head lease only

questions.explanation: The sublessor classifies the sublease based on the right-of-use asset from the head lease, not the underlying asset itself. This is an important distinction in ASC 842.
questions.tip: Sublease classification: based on ROU asset, not underlying asset.

questions.question: Leases between related parties should be classified based on:

options.B: The legally enforceable terms and conditions of the lease

questions.explanation: Related party leases are classified based on the legally enforceable terms and conditions, just like third-party leases. However, the economic substance should be disclosed.
questions.tip: Related party leases: classify based on legal terms.

questions.question: A company leases office space for $10,000/month including $2,000 for CAM (common area maintenance). If the company elects not to separate components, what is recorded as the lease payment?
questions.explanation: If the lessee elects the practical expedient not to separate lease and non-lease components, the entire payment ($10,000) is treated as the lease payment and included in the lease liability.
questions.tip: Non-separation election: all payments become lease payments.

questions.question: Under ASC 842, right-of-use assets should be tested for impairment in accordance with:

options.B: ASC 360 (Long-Lived Assets)
options.D: ASC 842 contains its own impairment guidance

questions.explanation: ROU assets are tested for impairment under ASC 360 (Property, Plant, and Equipment - Impairment) along with other long-lived assets in the asset group.
questions.tip: ROU asset impairment follows ASC 360 (long-lived assets).

questions.question: A lessee receives a $50,000 tenant improvement allowance from the lessor. The 5-year lease has payments of $30,000/year (PV = $126,000). What is the initial ROU asset (ignoring other adjustments)?
questions.explanation: ROU asset = Lease liability - Lease incentives received = $126,000 - $50,000 = $76,000.
questions.tip: Lease incentives reduce the ROU asset.

questions.question: A lessee should reassess the lease term when:

options.B: When there is a significant event or change in circumstances within lessee's control affecting likelihood of exercising options
options.C: Only when the lease is modified

questions.explanation: The lease term is reassessed when significant events or changes within the lessee's control affect the assessment of whether options will be exercised.
questions.tip: Reassess lease term only for significant lessee-controlled events.

questions.question: A lease liability is $100,000. Payments next year will reduce principal by $18,000 and interest by $8,000. How much is reported as current liability?
questions.explanation: The current portion of lease liability is the principal reduction expected within 12 months. Interest is not part of the liability; it's recognized as expense when incurred.
questions.tip: Current lease liability = principal payments due within 12 months.

questions.question: For a finance lease, cash payments are presented in the statement of cash flows as:

options.B: All in financing activities
options.C: Principal in financing, interest in operating (unless policy elects financing)

questions.explanation: Finance lease principal payments are classified as financing activities. Interest can be in operating activities (typical) or financing (if consistent policy elected).
questions.tip: Finance lease: principal = financing; interest = typically operating.

questions.question: Which is NOT a required ASC 842 disclosure for lessees?

options.B: Weighted-average discount rate

questions.explanation: Lessees disclose their own weighted-average remaining term, discount rate, and maturity analysis. The lessor's rate of return is not a required lessee disclosure.
questions.tip: Lessee disclosures focus on lessee's perspective, not lessor's.

questions.question: A contract contains an embedded lease if:

options.A: The contract is with a related party
options.B: There is an identified asset and the customer controls its use

questions.explanation: An embedded lease exists when the contract involves (1) an identified asset and (2) the customer has the right to control the use of that asset. Common in outsourcing and supply contracts.
questions.tip: Embedded lease = identified asset + customer controls use.

questions.question: A 3-year lease requires annual payments of $25,000 at the beginning of each period. At 6%, the PV of an ordinary annuity is 2.673 and PV of annuity due is 2.833. What is the lease liability?
questions.explanation: For beginning-of-period payments, use annuity due factor: $25,000 × 2.833 = $70,825.
questions.tip: Beginning of period = annuity due; End of period = ordinary annuity.

questions.question: When should a termination penalty be included in the lease liability?

options.A: Always, regardless of the likelihood of termination
options.B: When the lease term reflects the lessee exercising a termination option
options.C: Only if the penalty exceeds one year of payments
options.D: Never, penalties are expensed when paid

questions.explanation: Termination penalties are included in the lease liability only when the lease term assumes the termination option will be exercised.
questions.tip: Termination penalty: include only if termination is reflected in lease term.

questions.question: Under the FASB COVID-19 rent concession practical expedient, lessees may elect to account for qualifying rent concessions as:

options.B: Variable lease payments, avoiding lease modification accounting

questions.explanation: The practical expedient allows lessees to elect not to apply modification accounting to qualifying COVID-19 rent concessions, instead treating them as variable lease payments.
questions.tip: COVID concession expedient: treat as variable payments, skip modification accounting.

questions.question: A lease covers equipment ($60,000 SSP) and a vehicle ($40,000 SSP) for total payments of $80,000 (PV). What is allocated to the equipment ROU asset?
questions.tip: Allocate to multiple ROU assets based on relative SSP.
